ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The course was taught through a combination of live virtual lecture and live virtual seminar.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my reading comprehension abilities and my Vietnamese writing abilities. I was not really able to develop my communication abilities, however.

In this course, I had the opportunity to learn more about my heritage linguistically and culturally. I can now speak, read, and write more proficiently. I finally feel confident saying I am literate in my native language.
I learned how to read and write in Vietnamese.
I developed formal speaking, reading, and writing skills in Vietnamese

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course was that because of the small class size, students were able to actively participate in class and get direct feedback from the professor and TA. Both the professor and TA were also extremely lenient with grading and deadlines- they were more focused on students learning through completing the assignments than on harshly grading the assignments. The weakness of this course was that because the professor and TA were so lax with deadlines, they often did not communicate with students regarding what exact assignments students needed to complete.

This class covers topics most relevant to college students in conversation which is incredibly helpful. While the homework can be tedious and repetitive, it is helpful in cementing our writing skills. The course could be improved through more structure, particularly with communicating when quizzes will be further in advance.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor's incorporation of breakout rooms and group projects into the course were definitely helpful and promoted engagement between students and learning virtually. I do wish, however, that there was more opportunity to engage with the professor and TA virtually.

This class did well under pandemic/distance learning conditions. It would be helpful for the professor to have an undergraduate technology assistant who can also speak Vietnamese as there were many times class was disrupted due to technology issues. The students and professor worked through the issues together, but it would still be helpful to have a UTA.
This class could've benefited from having a technology assistant.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to Vietnamese students who regularly speak Vietnamese at home with their families and who are looking for either a course that will help improve their Vietnamese or an easy language course.

I would recommend this course to other Vietnamese heritage students. There is a noticeable difference in my Vietnamese now that makes it easier for me to communicate and connect with family members and the larger Vietnamese community. I began the course not being able to read or write Vietnamese well, beyond elementary words, but now I can read and write more fluently and comprehensively.
